intro: Polycarpon bivonae, commonly known as the Bivona's knotweed, is a flowering plant native to certain regions of Europe. It belongs to the family Amaranthaceae and is characterized by its erect, herbaceous stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, disturbed soils and is often found in wetlands or along stream banks. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are usually pink or red, adding a striking visual element to its habitat. Polycarpon bivonae is not widely cultivated but is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
